Linear Algebra Basics

  • Orthogonal/ Unitary Matrices Q∈Kn,nQ \in \mathbb{K}^{n,n}Q∈Kn,n﻿:
    • QQQ﻿ is orthogonal, if Q−1=QTQ^{-1} = Q^TQ−1=QT﻿
    • QQQ﻿ is unitary, if Q−1=QHQ^{-1} = Q^HQ−1=QH﻿
    • QQQ﻿ unitary   ⟺  ∣∣Qx∣∣2=∣∣x∣∣2,∀x∈Kn\iff ||Qx||_2 = ||x||_2, \forall x \in \mathbb{K}^n⟺∣∣Qx∣∣2​=∣∣x∣∣2​,∀x∈Kn﻿
    • QQQ﻿’s rows/ columns have euclidean norm 111﻿
    • All rows/ columns of QQQ﻿ are pairwise orthogonal
    • ∣det⁡Q∣=1|\det Q| = 1∣detQ∣=1﻿
    • ∣∣Q∣∣2=1||Q||_2 = 1∣∣Q∣∣2​=1﻿
    • ∣∣QA∣∣2=∣∣A∣∣2,∣∣QA∣∣F=∣∣A∣∣F||QA||_2 = ||A||_2, ||QA||_F = ||A||_F ∣∣QA∣∣2​=∣∣A∣∣2​,∣∣QA∣∣F​=∣∣A∣∣F​﻿
    • Let Q,PQ,PQ,P﻿ be orthogonal/unitary, then QPQPQP﻿ is orthogonal/unitary as well
  • Frobenius Norm ∣∣A∣∣F=∑i∑jaij2=∑iσi2||A||_F = \sqrt{\sum_i\sum_ja_{ij}^2}=\sqrt{\sum_i\sigma_i^2}∣∣A∣∣F​=∑i​∑j​aij2​​=∑i​σi2​​﻿
  • Matrix-2 Norm ∣∣A∣∣2=σmax(A)||A||_2 = \sigma_{max}(A)∣∣A∣∣2​=σmax​(A)﻿
  • For Wk=Span{w1,...,wk}⊂RnW_k = \text{Span}\{w_1,...,w_k\} \subset \R^nWk​=Span{w1​,...,wk​}⊂Rn﻿, The orthogonal projection of a point x∈Rnx \in \R^nx∈Rn﻿ onto WkW_kWk​﻿ is given by WWTxWW^TxWWTx﻿, where W=(w1 ... wk)W = (w_1 \ ... \ w_k)W=(w1​ ... wk​)﻿
  • For a matrix A∈Rm,n,ATAA \in \R^{m,n}, A^TAA∈Rm,n,ATA﻿ is positive semi-definite: xTATAx=(Ax)T(Ax)=∣∣Ax∣∣22≥0x^TA^TAx = (Ax)^T(Ax) = ||Ax||_2^2 \geq 0xTATAx=(Ax)T(Ax)=∣∣Ax∣∣22​≥0﻿
  • Image/ Range of A∈Rm,nA \in \R^{m,n}A∈Rm,n﻿: R(A)={Ax∣x∈Rn}⊂Rm\mathcal R(A) = \{Ax | x \in \R^n\} \subset \R^mR(A)={Ax∣x∈Rn}⊂Rm﻿
  • Kernel/ Nullspace of A∈Rm,nA \in \R^{m,n}A∈Rm,n﻿AA A﻿N(A)={x∈Rn∣Ax=0}⊂Rn\mathcal N(A) = \{x \in \R^n | Ax = 0\} \subset \R^nN(A)={x∈Rn∣Ax=0}⊂Rn﻿
  • N(ATA)=N(A),m≥n\mathcal N(A^TA) = \mathcal N(A), m\geq nN(ATA)=N(A),m≥n﻿
  • R(ATA)=R(AT),m≥n\mathcal R(A^TA) = \mathcal R(A^T), m \geq nR(ATA)=R(AT),m≥n﻿
  • rank(A)=rank(AT)\text{rank}(A) = \text{rank}(A^T)rank(A)=rank(AT)﻿
  • The orthogonal complement of a subspace V⊂RnV \subset \R^nV⊂Rn﻿ is given by V⊥={y∈Rn∣xHy=0,x∈V}V^\perp = \{y \in \R^n | x^Hy = 0 , x \in V \}V⊥={y∈Rn∣xHy=0,x∈V}﻿

(Week 3) Introduction to Numerical CS

Machine Precision (Epsilon)

  • Machine Precision is
    • an upper bound on the relative error due to rounding in floating point arithmetic
    • the difference between 111﻿ and the next floating point greater than 111﻿ (12#mantissa bits\frac{1}{2^{\text{\#mantissa bits}}}2#mantissa bits1​﻿)
  • eps∈O(10−16)\text{eps} \in O(10^{-16})eps∈O(10−16)﻿ for double precision

Floating Point Numbers

The definition from the script (not IEEE standard) defines machine numbers the following:

Given:

  • Basis BBB﻿
  • Range of possible exponents {emin,...,emax}\{e_{min}, ..., e_{max}\}{emin​,...,emax​}﻿
  • Number M∈NM \in \NM∈N﻿ of mantissa digits

The set of representable machine numbers is:

M={d⋅BE:d=iB−m,i∈{Bm−1,...,Bm−1}}\mathbb{M} = \{d \cdot B^E : d = iB^{-m}, i \in \{B^{m-1},...,B^m-1\}\}M={d⋅BE:d=iB−m,i∈{Bm−1,...,Bm−1}}﻿

In a bit (digit) - representation we require, that the mantissa never starts with leading zeros

Cancellation

A phenomenon that occurs whenever one tries to subtract two numbers that are nearly equal, both “carrying” a small relative error:

We try to compute x−yx-yx−y﻿, under the following conditions:

  • x=xopt+ε1x = x_{opt} + \varepsilon_1x=xopt​+ε1​﻿
  • y=yopt−ε2y = y_{opt} - \varepsilon_2y=yopt​−ε2​﻿
  • xopt≈yoptx_{opt} \approx y_{opt}xopt​≈yopt​﻿

Meaning x−y≈ε1+ε2x-y \approx \varepsilon_1 + \varepsilon_2x−y≈ε1​+ε2​﻿, which carries a way larger relative error now, since the number that x−yx-yx−y﻿ should actually represent would be very close to 000﻿

To avoid cancellation, we can check signs of the variables, and try to reformulate the equation such that we never have to subtract to numbers of about the same magnitude.

(Week 4) Linear Systems of Equations

Definition

A linear system of equations (LSE) of mmm﻿ equations and nnn﻿ unknowns can be written as:

Ax=b,A∈Rm,nAx = b, A \in \R^{m,n}Ax=b,A∈Rm,n﻿

We can solve a LSE using Gaussian elimination, or compute the LU decomposition of AAA﻿, A=LUA = LUA=LU﻿, where LLL﻿ is lower triangular and UUU﻿ is upper triangular.

Having AAA﻿ in it’s LU-form, allows us to solve the LSE in O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)﻿ instead of using Gaussian elimination which takes O(n3)O(n^3)O(n3)﻿, note however that computing the Lu decomposition is just as fast as Gauss.

The LU decomposition (with pivoting) exists for all (square) regular matrices.

Sparse Matrix Formats

CRS

Saves all nnz\text{nnz}nnz﻿ entries of the original matrix in an Array (length=#nnz\text{length} = \# \text{nnz}length=#nnz﻿). Saves all the column indices of these entries in a second array, in order of top to bottom going row by row in the original matrix. The third array, the rowPtr\text{rowPtr}rowPtr﻿, saves for every row-index the lowest index in the array with the column-indexes, where an element is in the i-th row.

Storage complexity is 2⋅#nnz+n+12 \cdot \text{\#nnz} + n +1 2⋅#nnz+n+1﻿

CCS := Compressed column storage (Same as CRS, But with rowInd and colPtr)

COO

Saves all nnz\text{nnz}nnz﻿ entries of the matrix in a triplet (i,j,v)(i,j,v)(i,j,v)﻿, where iii﻿ is the row-index, jjj﻿ the column-index and vvv﻿ the value of the entry.

Storage complexity is 3∗#nnz3* \text{\#nnz}3∗#nnz﻿

Sparse-Ellpack-Format (goofy COO)

Saves all nnz\text{nnz}nnz﻿ entries of the matrix in a matrix in their respective rows and the column-indices in a second matrix in the same format.

Storage complexity for a m×nm \times nm×n﻿ matrix is 2⋅m⋅max(#nnz in a single row)2 \cdot m \cdot \text{max}(\text{\#nnz in a single row})2⋅m⋅max(#nnz in a single row)﻿

Sparse Matrix Solving in Eigen

VectorXd x(n), b(n);
SparseMatrix<double> A;
SparseLU<SparseMatrix<double>, COLAMDOrdering<int>> solver;
// fill A and b;
// Compute the ordering permutation vector from the structural pattern of A
solver.analyzePattern(A); 
// Compute the numerical factorization 
solver.factorize(A); 
//Use the factors to solve the linear system 
x = solver.solve(b);

(Week 5) Least Squares & Normal Equation

Problem Definition

We want to solve a system Ax=b,A∈Rm,n,x∈Rn,b∈Rm,m≥nAx = b, A \in \R^{m,n}, x \in \R^n, b \in \R^m, m \geq nAx=b,A∈Rm,n,x∈Rn,b∈Rm,m≥n﻿. We want to find the “solution” x∗x^*x∗﻿, that minimizes ∣∣Ax−b∣∣22||Ax-b||_2^2∣∣Ax−b∣∣22​﻿. This kind of solution is of great interest, since an exact solution to Ax=bAx = bAx=b﻿ requires b∈R(A)b \in \mathcal R(A)b∈R(A)﻿. If perturbations of bbb﻿, for example measurement errors slightly alter the “perfect” bbb﻿, we wont find a solution xxx﻿.

  • Definition Least Squares solution:

    x∗=arg min⁡x∈Rn∣∣Ax−b∣∣22x^* = \argmin_{x \in \R^n} ||Ax-b||_2^2x∗=argminx∈Rn​∣∣Ax−b∣∣22​﻿

A Least Squares solution xxx﻿ is any vector that minimizes the euclidean norm of the residual r=b−Axr = b - Axr=b−Ax﻿. We write lsq(A,b)⊂Rn\text{lsq}(A,b) \subset \R^nlsq(A,b)⊂Rn﻿ for the set containing all such vectors xxx﻿.

Least Squares solutions are a generalization of the “normal” exact solution to a LSE, where the norm of the residual would equal 000﻿.

Geometrically the/a Least Squares solution xxx﻿ is the xxx﻿, that minimizes the distance between the Hyperplane R(A)\mathcal R(A)R(A)﻿ and the vector bbb﻿. All solutions xxx﻿ are the exact solutions to the system Ax=b^Ax = \hat bAx=b^﻿, where b^\hat bb^﻿ is the orthogonal projection of bbb﻿ onto R(A)\mathcal R(A)R(A)﻿.

  • lsq(A,b)\text{lsq}(A,b) lsq(A,b)﻿ is an affine subspace of Rn\R^nRn﻿
  • lsq(A,b)=x0+N(A),x0∈lsq(A,b)  ⟹  lsq(A,b) ∣∣ N(A) \text{lsq}(A,b) = x_0 + \mathcal N (A), x_0 \in \text{lsq}(A,b) \implies \text{lsq}(A,b) \ || \ \mathcal N (A)lsq(A,b)=x0​+N(A),x0​∈lsq(A,b)⟹lsq(A,b) ∣∣ N(A)﻿
  • dim⁡lsq(A,b)=dim⁡N(A)=n−rank(A)\dim \text{lsq}(A,b) = \dim \mathcal N(A) =n- \text{rank}(A)dimlsq(A,b)=dimN(A)=n−rank(A)﻿
  • The residual r=b−Axr = b - Axr=b−Ax﻿ described above is orthogonal to R(A)\mathcal R(A)R(A)﻿: r=b−Ax⊥R(A)r = b-Ax \perp \mathcal R(A)r=b−Ax⊥R(A)﻿
  • This obviously also applies to all columns of AAA﻿, A:,i⊥rA_{:,i} \perp rA:,i​⊥r﻿, thus ATr=0nA^Tr = 0_nATr=0n​﻿

Normal Equation

The above hints (not a proof), that xxx﻿ is a solution to the Least Squares problem   ⟺  \iff⟺﻿ATr=AT(b−Ax)=ATb−ATAx=0  ⟺  ATAx=ATbA^Tr = A^T(b-Ax) =A^Tb - A^TAx = 0 \iff A^TAx = A^TbATr=AT(b−Ax)=ATb−ATAx=0⟺ATAx=ATb﻿ is full-filled

The equations ATAx=ATbA^TAx = A^TbATAx=ATb﻿ are called the normal equation (NEQ). Solving this LSE gives lsq(A,b)\text{lsq}(A,b)lsq(A,b)﻿

The Least Squares solution for a matrix A∈Rm,nA \in \R^{m,n}A∈Rm,n﻿ is unique, if N(A)={0}\mathcal N(A) = \{0\}N(A)={0}﻿, note that ATAA^TAATA﻿ is positive definite in that case.

  • For m>n, N(A)={0}  ⟺  rank(A)=nm > n, \ \mathcal N(A) = \{0\} \iff \text{rank}(A) = nm>n, N(A)={0}⟺rank(A)=n﻿

If the rank condition is not full-filled in a 2d linear regression example, then we are not able to fix a line that fits our points, since they all lie on a vertical line.

Moore Penrose Pseudoinverse

We first define the generalized Least Squares solution:

x†=arg min⁡x∈lsq(A,b)∣∣x∣∣2x^\dag = \argmin_{x \in \text{lsq}(A,b)}||x||_2x†=argminx∈lsq(A,b)​∣∣x∣∣2​﻿

This is the solution which is the nearest to the origin (so it’s orthogonal to the solution space lsq(A,b)\text{lsq}(A,b)lsq(A,b)﻿, and also orthogonal to N(A)\mathcal N(A)N(A)﻿, since lsq(A,b) ∣∣ N(A)\text{lsq}(A,b) \ || \ \mathcal N(A)lsq(A,b) ∣∣ N(A)﻿)

We find a formula for the generalized Least Squares solution:

x†=V(VTATAV)−1(VTATb)x^\dag = V(V^TA^TAV)^{-1}(V^TA^Tb)x†=V(VTATAV)−1(VTATb)﻿

  • We call A†=V(VTATAV)−1VTATA^\dag =V(V^TA^TAV)^{-1}V^TA^TA†=V(VTATAV)−1VTAT﻿ the Moore Penrose Pseudo Inverse of AAA﻿, where VVV﻿ is a matrix whose columns form a basis for N(A)⊥\mathcal N(A)^\perpN(A)⊥﻿

NEQ method to solve full rank LSQ

Least Squares has unique solution  ⟸  \impliedby⟸﻿ FRC (Full rank condition)   ⟺  \iff ⟺﻿rank(A)=n  ⟺  ATA \text{rank}(A) = n \iff A^TArank(A)=n⟺ATA﻿ regular

  • Compute C=ATAC =A^TAC=ATA﻿ and z=ATbz = A^Tbz=ATb﻿
  • Solve Cx=zCx = zCx=z﻿

Computational cost: O(n2m+n3)O(n^2m+n^3)O(n2m+n3)﻿

If matrix AAA﻿ is sparse, ATAA^TAATA﻿ is generally speaking not sparse, the following trick helps:

Extended Normal Equations

ATAx=ATb  ⟺  AT(b−Ax)=0  ⟺  ATr=0A^TAx = A^Tb \iff A^T(b-Ax) = 0 \iff A^Tr = 0ATAx=ATb⟺AT(b−Ax)=0⟺ATr=0﻿

Leading to the LSE:

I:r=(b−Ax)I: r = (b-Ax)I:r=(b−Ax)﻿

II:ATr=0II: A^Tr = 0II:ATr=0﻿

[IAAT0]⏟C[rx]=[b0]\underbrace{\begin{bmatrix}I & A\\A^T & 0\end{bmatrix}}_{C}\begin{bmatrix}r \\x\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}b \\0\end{bmatrix}C[IAT​A0​]​​[rx​]=[b0​]﻿, and CCC﻿ is sparse, if AAA﻿ is sparse

(Week 6) QR

Consider a matrix A∈Rn,kA \in \mathbb{R}^{n,k}A∈Rn,k﻿, with rank kkk﻿:

  • Economical QR

    It exists a unique matrix Q0∈Rn,kQ_0 \in \R^{n,k}Q0​∈Rn,k﻿ that satisfies Q0HQ0=IkQ_0^HQ_0 = I_kQ0H​Q0​=Ik​﻿ and a unique upper triangular matrix R0∈Rk,kR_0 \in \R^{k,k}R0​∈Rk,k﻿ with (R)i,i>0(R)_{i,i} > 0(R)i,i​>0﻿, such that A=Q0R0A = Q_0R_0A=Q0​R0​﻿

  • Full QR

    It exists a unitary matrix Q∈Rn,nQ \in \R^{n,n}Q∈Rn,n﻿ and a unique upper triangular R∈Rn,kR \in \R^{n,k}R∈Rn,k﻿, with (R)i,i>0(R)_{i,i} > 0(R)i,i​>0﻿, such that A=QRA = QRA=QR﻿

  • The economical QR is unique if we demand (R0)i,i>0(R_0)_{i,i} > 0(R0​)i,i​>0﻿
  • Visualisation

Householder-Reflections:

  • H(v)=I−2vvTvTvH(v) = I-2\frac{vv^T}{v^Tv}H(v)=I−2vTvvvT​﻿
  • v=a+sign(a1)∣∣a∣∣2e1v = a +\text{sign}(a_1)||a||_2e_1v=a+sign(a1​)∣∣a∣∣2​e1​﻿

We need to perform n−1n-1n−1﻿ iterations, where we multiply with a Householder matrix. We denote the iii﻿-th Householder matrix with QiQ_iQi​﻿. If we try to decompose matrix A∈Rm,nA \in \R^{m,n}A∈Rm,n﻿ with column vectors aia_iai​﻿, our QiQ_iQi​﻿’s look the following:

Q1=H(a1)Q_1 = H(a_1)Q1​=H(a1​)﻿

Q2=[100H(aˉ2)],aˉ2=(a22,a32,...,am2)TQ_2 = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0\\ 0 & H(\bar{a}_2)\end{bmatrix}, \bar{a}_2 = (a_{22},a_{32}, ..., a_{m2})^TQ2​=[10​0H(aˉ2​)​],aˉ2​=(a22​,a32​,...,am2​)T﻿

⋮\vdots⋮﻿

Qn−1=[11⋱H(aˉn−1)],aˉn−1=(an−1,n−1,an,n−1)TQ_{n-1} = \begin{bmatrix}1 & & \\ & 1 & & \\ & & \ddots & \\ & & & H(\bar{a}_{n-1}) \end{bmatrix}, \bar{a}_{n-1} = (a_{n-1,n-1}, a_{n,n-1})^TQn−1​=​1​1​⋱​H(aˉn−1​)​​,aˉn−1​=(an−1,n−1​,an,n−1​)T﻿

Then the following holds:

  • Qn−1...Q2Q1A=RQ_{n-1}...Q_2Q_1A = RQn−1​...Q2​Q1​A=R﻿
  • Conversely Q=Q1TQ2T...Qn−1TQ =Q_1^TQ_2^T...Q_{n-1}^TQ=Q1T​Q2T​...Qn−1T​﻿, for the QR-decomposition A=QRA = QRA=QR﻿

In practice one only needs to store one vectors (namely vvv﻿), to uniquely identify a Householder reflection, or store one of the QiQ_iQi​﻿’s.

  • Visualisation

Givens-Rotations:

We will denote a Givens-Rotation by Gij(ai,aj),i<jG_{ij}(a_i,a_j), i < jGij​(ai​,aj​),i<j﻿. This is a matrix, acting on a vector aaa﻿. If we start decomposing our matrix A∈Rm,nA\in \R^{m,n}A∈Rm,n﻿, and we want to “zero out” a2,1a_{2,1}a2,1​﻿, then we compute cˉ1=G12(a1,a2)(A):,1\bar{c}_1 = G_{12}(a_1,a_2)(A)_{:,1}cˉ1​=G12​(a1​,a2​)(A):,1​﻿, and replace our first column in AAA﻿ with cˉ1\bar{c}_1cˉ1​﻿. Then we start eliminating the next element, a3,1a_{3,1}a3,1​﻿.

Gij(ai,aj)G_{ij}(a_i,a_j)Gij​(ai​,aj​)﻿ looks like this (attacks matrix element ajia_{ji}aji​﻿):

G=Gij(ai,aj)=[γ…σ…0⋮⋱⋮⋮−σ…γ…0⋮⋮⋱⋮0…0…1]⏟i j,γ=ai∣ai∣2+∣aj∣2,σ=aj∣ai∣2+∣aj∣2,±(γ,σ)G = G_{ij}(a_i,a_j) = \underbrace{\begin{bmatrix} \gamma & \dots & \sigma & \dots & 0 \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots & & \vdots \\ -\sigma & \dots & \gamma & \dots & 0 \\ \vdots & & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & \dots & 0 & \dots & 1\end{bmatrix}}_{i \qquad \qquad \ j \qquad \qquad }, \quad \gamma = \frac{a_i}{\sqrt{|a_i|^2+|a_j|^2}}, \sigma = \frac{a_j}{\sqrt{|a_i|^2+|a_j|^2}}, \pm (\gamma, \sigma)G=Gij​(ai​,aj​)=i j​γ⋮−σ⋮0​…⋱……​σ⋮γ⋮0​……⋱…​0⋮0⋮1​​​​,γ=∣ai​∣2+∣aj​∣2​ai​​,σ=∣ai​∣2+∣aj​∣2​aj​​,±(γ,σ)﻿

We do not need to do a huge matrix product like before though, since GGG﻿ only acts on very few elements in AAA﻿.

When storing GGG﻿, we only need to store one floating point number ρ\rhoρ﻿ (along with the corresponding indices). This also makes intuitive sense, since we only need to store an angle. We later need to recover γ\gammaγ﻿ and σ\sigmaσ﻿ from ρ\rhoρ﻿:

ρ≔{1, γ=012sign(γ)σ,  ∣σ∣<∣γ∣2sign(σ)/γ, else\rho \coloneqq \begin{cases}1, \qquad \qquad \ \gamma = 0\\ \frac 1 2 \text{sign}(\gamma)\sigma, \ \ |\sigma| < |\gamma| \\ 2\text{sign}(\sigma)/\gamma, \ \text{else}\end{cases}ρ:=⎩⎨⎧​1, γ=021​sign(γ)σ,  ∣σ∣<∣γ∣2sign(σ)/γ, else​﻿ recovering: {ρ=1  ⟹  γ=0,σ=1,∣ρ∣<1  ⟹  σ=2ρ,γ=1−σ2∣ρ∣>1  ⟹  γ=2/ρ,σ=1−γ2\begin{cases} \rho = 1 \implies \gamma = 0, \sigma = 1, \\ |\rho| < 1 \implies \sigma = 2\rho, \gamma = \sqrt{1-\sigma^2} \\ |\rho| > 1 \implies \gamma = 2/\rho, \sigma = \sqrt{1-\gamma^2} \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​ρ=1⟹γ=0,σ=1,∣ρ∣<1⟹σ=2ρ,γ=1−σ2​∣ρ∣>1⟹γ=2/ρ,σ=1−γ2​​﻿

QR-Decomposition in Eigen

Initialize: Eigen::HouseholderQR<MatrixXd> qr(A)

  • Full QR:
    • QQQ﻿: MatrixXd Q = qr.householderQ()
    • RRR﻿: MatrixXd R = qr.matrixQR().template triangularView<Eigen::Upper>()
  • Economical QR:
    • QQQ﻿: MatrixXd Q = qr.householderQ()*MatrixXd::Identity(m,n)
    • RRR﻿: MatrixXd R = qr.matrixQR().block(0,0,n,n).template triangularView<Eigen::Upper>()

Least Squares mit QR

We want to solve an overdetermined system Ax=b,A=QR∈Rm,n,m≥nAx = b, A = QR \in \R^{m,n}, m \geq nAx=b,A=QR∈Rm,n,m≥n﻿ with rank nnn﻿.
Observe:
∣∣Ax−b∣∣2=∣∣QRx−b∣∣2=∣∣Q(Rx−QTb)∣∣2=∣∣Rx−b^∣∣2,b^=QTb||Ax-b||_2 = ||QRx-b||_2 = ||Q(Rx-Q^Tb)||_2 = ||Rx-\hat b||_2, \hat b = Q^Tb∣∣Ax−b∣∣2​=∣∣QRx−b∣∣2​=∣∣Q(Rx−QTb)∣∣2​=∣∣Rx−b^∣∣2​,b^=QTb﻿

Now the solution x∗=R0−1b^1,nx^* = R_0^{-1}\hat b_{1,n}x∗=R0−1​b^1,n​﻿, since all rows after row nnn﻿ in RRR﻿ are 000﻿, so R0R_0R0​﻿ is just RRR﻿’s first nnn﻿ rows (an n×nn\times nn×n﻿ matrix). The residual is given by r=Q[0⋮0b^n+1⋮b^m]r = Q \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ \vdots \\ 0 \\ \hat{b}_{n+1} \\ \vdots \\ \hat{b}_m \end{bmatrix}r=Q​0⋮0b^n+1​⋮b^m​​​﻿, which implies that the norm of the residual is: ∣∣r∣∣2=b^n+12+...+b^m||r||_2 = \sqrt{\hat b_{n+1}^2 + ... + \hat b_m}∣∣r∣∣2​=b^n+12​+...+b^m​​﻿

In Eigen: VectorXd x = A.householderQr().solve(b) to solve a LSE

(Week 7) SVD

Properties of the SVD

Consider a matrix A∈Km,nA \in \mathbb{K}^{m,n}A∈Km,n﻿, (p≔min⁡(m,n)p\coloneqq \min(m,n)p:=min(m,n)﻿):

We call A=UΣVHA = U\Sigma V^HA=UΣVH﻿ the singular value decomposition (SVD) of AAA﻿

  • The SVD exists for every matrix A∈Km,nA \in \mathbb{K}^{m,n}A∈Km,n﻿
  • The SVD is not unique. Even if the singular values are sorted σ1≥σ2≥...≥σp≥0\sigma_1 \geq \sigma_2 \geq ... \geq \sigma_p \geq 0σ1​≥σ2​≥...≥σp​≥0﻿, since there may be σi=σj\sigma_i=\sigma_jσi​=σj​﻿ allowing permutation of the corresponding left/right singular vectors
    • Strictly sorted singular values σ1>σ2>...>σp>0\sigma_1 > \sigma_2 > ... > \sigma_p > 0σ1​>σ2​>...>σp​>0﻿ would result in a unique SVD
  • U∈Km,m,V∈Kn,nU \in \mathbb{K}^{m,m},V \in \mathbb{K}^{n,n}U∈Km,m,V∈Kn,n﻿ unitary matrices, containing the left/right singular vectors of AAA﻿
    • The left singular vectors of AAA﻿, namely (U):,1,...(U):,p(U)_{:,1},...(U)_{:,p}(U):,1​,...(U):,p​﻿ are the eigenvectors of AAHAA^HAAH﻿
    • The right singular vectors of AAA﻿, namely (V):,1,...(V):,p(V)_{:,1},...(V)_{:,p}(V):,1​,...(V):,p​﻿ are the eigenvectors of AHAA^HAAHA﻿
  • Σ∈Km,n=diag(σ1,...,σp)\Sigma \in \mathbb{K}^{m,n} = \text{diag}(\sigma_1, ..., \sigma_p)Σ∈Km,n=diag(σ1​,...,σp​)﻿ (zero extended) contains the singular values of AAA﻿
    • σi2\sigma_i^2σi2​﻿ are the eigenvalues of AAH,AHAAA^H, A^HAAAH,AHA﻿ for 1≤i≤p1 \leq i \leq p1≤i≤p﻿
    • Thus the singular values are unique up to permutations along the diagonal of Σ\SigmaΣ﻿
  • The above points can be proved using the Spectral Decomposition of AAH,AHAAA^H, A^HAAAH,AHA﻿ (they are symmetric, thus diagonalizable)
  • Let 1≤r≤p1 \leq r \leq p1≤r≤p﻿ be the index of the last non-zero singular value σr\sigma_rσr​﻿, then:
    • rank(A)=r\text{rank}(A) = rrank(A)=r﻿
    • R(A)=Span((U):,1,...,((U):,r))\mathcal R (A) = \text{Span}( (U)_{:,1},... ,((U)_{:,r}))R(A)=Span((U):,1​,...,((U):,r​))﻿
    • N(AH)=Span((U):,r+1,...,(U):,n)\mathcal N (A^H) = \text{Span}((U)_{:,r+1}, ..., (U)_{:,n})N(AH)=Span((U):,r+1​,...,(U):,n​)﻿
    • R(AH)=Span((V):,1,...,((V):,r))\mathcal R (A^H) = \text{Span}((V)_{:,1},... ,((V)_{:,r}))R(AH)=Span((V):,1​,...,((V):,r​))﻿
    • N(A)=Span((V):,r+1,...,(V):,n)\mathcal N (A) = \text{Span}((V)_{:,r+1}, ..., (V)_{:,n})N(A)=Span((V):,r+1​,...,(V):,n​)﻿

Economical SVD

U∈Km,pU\in \mathbb K^{m,p}U∈Km,p﻿, Σ∈Kp,p\Sigma\in \mathbb K^{p,p}Σ∈Kp,p﻿, V∈Kp,nV\in \mathbb K^{p,n}V∈Kp,n﻿

SVD In Eigen

  • Regular SVD: Eigen::JacobiSVD<MatrixXd> s(A, Eigen::ComputeFullU | Eigen::ComputeFullV)
  • Economical SVD: Eigen::JacobiSVD<MatrixXd> s(A, Eigen::ComputeThinU | Eigen::ComputeThinV)
  • UUU﻿: s.matrixU()
  • VVV﻿: s.matrixV()
  • Σ\SigmaΣ﻿: sigma = s.singularValues() returns a Vector containing the singular values in descending order, get the matrix by: sigma.asDiagonal()

Least Squares using SVD

The solution to an overdetermined Least Squares problem Ax=bAx = bAx=b﻿ is given by: x∗=V1Σr−1U1Hbx^* = V_1\Sigma_r^{-1}U_1^Hbx∗=V1​Σr−1​U1H​b﻿, wobei r=rank(A)r = \text{rank}(A)r=rank(A)﻿, und V1,U1V_1,U_1V1​,U1​﻿ jeweils die ersten rrr﻿ Spalten von VVV﻿, bzw. UUU﻿ sind

Exercise:

  • Provide the general solution of the Least Squares problem Ax=b,A=uvT,u∈Rm,v∈RnAx=b, A = uv^T, u \in \R^m,v\in \R^nAx=b,A=uvT,u∈Rm,v∈Rn﻿

    We compute the SVD of AAA﻿. A=u^∣∣u∣∣2∣∣v∣∣2v^A =\hat u ||u||_2 ||v||_2 \hat vA=u^∣∣u∣∣2​∣∣v∣∣2​v^﻿, where x^\hat xx^﻿ is the normalized vector of x=x∣∣x∣∣2x = \frac{x}{||x||_2}x=∣∣x∣∣2​x​﻿. Now we apply the formula for the general least squares solution: x∗=V1Σr−1U1Hb=v^1∣∣u∣∣2∣∣v∣∣2u^Hb=vuH∣∣u∣∣22∣∣v∣∣22bx^* = V_1\Sigma_r^{-1}U_1^Hb = \hat v \frac{1}{||u||_2||v||_2}\hat u^Hb = \frac{vu^H}{||u||_2^2||v||_2^2}bx∗=V1​Σr−1​U1H​b=v^∣∣u∣∣2​∣∣v∣∣2​1​u^Hb=∣∣u∣∣22​∣∣v∣∣22​vuH​b﻿

Pseudo Inverse using SVD

The Pseudo Inverse of a matrix AAA﻿ is given by A†=V1Σr−1U1HA^\dag = V_1\Sigma_r^{-1}U_1^HA†=V1​Σr−1​U1H​﻿ (Least Squares term without bbb﻿)

Low Rank Approximation

Let rrr﻿ be the rank of a matrix AAA﻿. The best rank-kkk﻿ approximation of AAA﻿ is given by Ak=∑i=1kσi(U:,i)(V):,iHA_k = \sum_{i=1}^k \sigma_i(U_{:,i})(V)_{:,i}^HAk​=∑i=1k​σi​(U:,i​)(V):,iH​﻿

Intuitively the more singular values and their corresponding left/right singular vectors we add to our approximation, the better we get. The greatest singular value is therefore the most “significant” one. Singular values of greater magnitude have a larger impact on the resulting linear map, smaller ones are not that “important” but give a level of detail.

The error of our approximation is given by ∣∣A−Ak∣∣F2=∑j=k+1pσj2||A-A_k||_F^2 = \sum_{j = k+1}^p\sigma_j^2∣∣A−Ak​∣∣F2​=∑j=k+1p​σj2​﻿, or ∣∣A−Ak∣∣22=σk+1||A-A_k||_2^2 = \sigma_{k+1}∣∣A−Ak​∣∣22​=σk+1​﻿ respectively

Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

Example:
Let
A∈Rm,nA \in \R^{m,n}A∈Rm,n﻿ be a matrix formed by aj∈Rma_j \in \R^maj​∈Rm﻿ column vectors. Every one of these vectors gives the stock price of stock jjj﻿ on day iii﻿ (aija_{ij}aij​﻿). We now want to determine trends in our data set, that are formed by these stock prices. We use the SVD of our matrix A=UΣVHA = U \Sigma V^HA=UΣVH﻿ for that.

Note: A=∑i=1pσi(U:,i)(V):,iHA = \sum_{i = 1}^{p}\sigma_i(U_{:,i})(V)_{:,i}^HA=∑i=1p​σi​(U:,i​)(V):,iH​﻿

We distinguish three cases:

  1. One trend vector (very very unlikely)

    This means, that all nnn﻿ stocks trends can be described by a single vector u∈Rmu \in \R^mu∈Rm﻿: aj∈Span(u),∀ja_j \in \text{Span}(u), \forall jaj​∈Span(u),∀j﻿

  1. No perturbation (very unlikely)

    This means, that our singular values look roughly like: σ1≥σ2≥...≥σr>σr+1=...=σp=0\sigma_1 \geq \sigma_2 \geq ... \geq \sigma_r > \sigma_{r+1} = ... = \sigma_p = 0σ1​≥σ2​≥...≥σr​>σr+1​=...=σp​=0﻿.

  1. Perturbation (likely)

    In this case almost all singular values are non-zero but there are a lot of singular values really close to zero, meaning there is a lot of detail we do not want to consider. The singular values probably look somewhat like this: σ1≥σ2≥...≥σr>>σr+1≈...≈σp\sigma_1 \geq \sigma_2 \geq ... \geq \sigma_r >> \sigma_{r+1} \approx ... \approx \sigma_pσ1​≥σ2​≥...≥σr​>>σr+1​≈...≈σp​﻿

In cases 2 and 3 the first rrr﻿ columns (left singular vectors) of UUU﻿ give us the rrr﻿ trend vectors (normalized). The corresponding singular values tell us the significance of each trend U:,1U_{:,1}U:,1​﻿ being the most present trend.

Proper Orthogonal decomposition (POD)

The problem asks to find a subspace WWW﻿ of dimension kkk﻿ (or rather the basis vectors of that subspace), which minimizes the distance (orthogonal) that datapoints aja_jaj​﻿ have to that subspace.

We essentially ask: S=arg min⁡W⊂Rm∑i=1ninf⁡w∈W∣∣ai−w∣∣22S =\argmin_{W\subset \R^m} \sum_{i = 1}^n \inf_{w \in W} ||a_i - w||_2^2S=argminW⊂Rm​∑i=1n​infw∈W​∣∣ai​−w∣∣22​﻿

Rewriting in matrix terms, we ask to minimize ∣∣A−WWTA∣∣F2||A-WW^TA||_F^2∣∣A−WWTA∣∣F2​﻿, where we ask for the kkk﻿ column vectors, that will span our space in W∈Rm,kW \in \R^{m,k}W∈Rm,k﻿

This is minimized by W=UkW = U_kW=Uk​﻿, with Uk∈Rm,kU_k \in \R^{m,k}Uk​∈Rm,k﻿ from A=UΣVHA = U\Sigma V^HA=UΣVH﻿’s best rank-kkk﻿ approximation

(Week 8) Discrete Signals & Convolution & DFT

Discrete Finite Linear Time-Invariant Causal Channels/Filters

  • A channel/filter is called finite, if every input signal of finite duration produces an output signal of finite duration
  • A filter is called time-invariant, if shifting the input in time leads to the same output shifted in time by the same amount
  • A filter is called linear, if it is a linear mapping
  • A filter is called casual, if the output does not start before the input
  • LT-FIR: Finite, linear, time-invariant and casual filter
  • The impluse response (IR) of a channel is the output for a single unit impulse at t=0t=0t=0﻿ as input.

Convolutions

  • (xm)∗(yn)∈Km+n−1(x_m)*(y_n)\in\mathbb K ^{m+n-1}(xm​)∗(yn​)∈Km+n−1﻿
  • (xn)∗n(yn)∈Kn(x_n)*_n(y_n)\in \mathbb K^{n}(xn​)∗n​(yn​)∈Kn﻿
  • If well defined, the (periodic) convolution commutes
  • (xn)∗(xn)=0(x_n)*(x_n)=0(xn​)∗(xn​)=0﻿ implies that (xn)=0(x_n)=0(xn​)=0﻿
  • (xn)∗n(xn)=0(x_n)*_n(x_n)=0(xn​)∗n​(xn​)=0﻿ implies that (xn)=0(x_n)=0(xn​)=0﻿
  • (xm)∗(yn)=0(x_m)*(y_n)=0(xm​)∗(yn​)=0﻿ implies that either (xm)=0(x_m)=0(xm​)=0﻿ or (yn)=0(y_n)=0(yn​)=0﻿

Given two vectors h∈Kn\mathrm h\in \mathbb K^nh∈Kn﻿, x∈Km\mathrm x\in \mathbb K^mx∈Km﻿, their convolution can be computed via periodic convolution as follows

where h~:=[h,0]⊤∈Kn+m−1\tilde{\mathrm h}:=[\mathrm h,0]^{\top} \in \mathbb K^{n+m-1}h~:=[h,0]⊤∈Kn+m−1﻿ and x~:=[x,0]⊤∈Kn+m−1\tilde{\mathrm x}:=[\mathrm x,0]^\top \in \mathbb K^{n+m-1}x~:=[x,0]⊤∈Kn+m−1﻿ are zero padded vectors.

Circulant matrices

A matrix C=[cij]i,j=1n∈Kn,n\mathbf{C}=\left[c_{i j}\right]_{i, j=1}^n \in \mathbb{K}^{n, n}C=[cij​]i,j=1n​∈Kn,n﻿ is circulant   ⟺  ∃(pk)k∈Z\iff \exists\left(p_k\right)_{k \in \mathbb{Z}}⟺∃(pk​)k∈Z​﻿n nn﻿-periodic sequence: cij=pi−j,1≤i,j≤n.c_{i j}=p_{i-j}, 1 \leq i, j \leq n .cij​=pi−j​,1≤i,j≤n.﻿

  • Structure of a generic circulant matrix

Fourier matrix

The matrix effecting the change of basis trigonometrical basis →standard basis\text{trigonometrical basis }\to \text{standard basis}trigonometrical basis →standard basis﻿ is called the Fourier-matrix:

The inverse Fourier matrix is defined as Fn−1=1nFnH\mathbf F_n^{-1}=\frac{1}{n}\mathbf F_n^\text HFn−1​=n1​FnH​﻿.

Discrete Fourier transform (DFT)

The multiplication with Fourier-matrices will be a crucial operation in algorithms for circulant matrices and discrete convolutions. Therefore this operation has been given a special name:

The linear map DFTn:Cn↦Cn,DFT⁡n(y):=Fny,y∈Cn\mathrm{DFT}_n: \mathbb{C}^n \mapsto \mathbb{C}^n, \operatorname{DFT}_n(\mathbf{y}):=\mathbf{F}_n \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{y} \in \mathbb{C}^nDFTn​:Cn↦Cn,DFTn​(y):=Fn​y,y∈Cn﻿, is called discrete Fourier transform (DFT)(\mathrm{DFT})(DFT)﻿, i.e. for [c0,…,cn−1]:=DFT⁡n(y)\left[c_0, \ldots, c_{n-1}\right]:=\operatorname{DFT}_n(\mathbf{y})[c0​,…,cn−1​]:=DFTn​(y)﻿

The result of DFT, c=DFT⁡n(y)=Fny\mathbf{c}=\operatorname{DFT}_n(\mathbf{y})=\mathbf{F}_n \mathbf{y}c=DFTn​(y)=Fn​y﻿, is also called the (discrete) Fourier transform of y\mathbf yy﻿.

From Fn−1=1nF‾n \mathbf{F}_n^{-1}=\frac{1}{n} \overline{\mathbf{F}}_nFn−1​=n1​Fn​﻿ we find the inverse discrete Fourier transform:

Eigen::VectorXcd periodicConvolution(const Eigen::VectorXcd &u, const Eigen::VectorXcd &x) {
		Eigen::FFT<double> fft;
		return fft.inv(((fft.fwd(u)).cwiseProduct(fft.fwd(x))).eval());
}

(Week 9) 2D DFT & FFT

2D DFT

The 2-dimensional DFT computes the frequencies that make up a signal, where the signal is two dimensional (an image for example).

To compute the 2D DFT of a signal (matrix AAA﻿) of size m×nm \times nm×n﻿, we have the following formula:

DFT(A)=FnAFm\text{DFT}(A) = F_nAF_mDFT(A)=Fn​AFm​﻿, FiF_iFi​﻿ being the Fourier matrix of size i×ii \times ii×i﻿

The convolution of two m×nm \times nm×n﻿ signals X,YX,YX,Y﻿ is given by:

X∗m,nY=DFTm,n−1(DFTm,n(X)⊙DFTm,n(Y))X *_{m,n}Y = DFT_{m,n}^{-1}(DFT_{m,n}(X) ⊙ DFT_{m,n}(Y))X∗m,n​Y=DFTm,n−1​(DFTm,n​(X)⊙DFTm,n​(Y))﻿

Fourier Coefficients

When computing the 1D DFT of a signal x∈Rnx \in \R^nx∈Rn﻿, we obtain coefficients ckc_kck​﻿. The moduli ∣ck∣=∣cn−k∣|c_k| = |c_{n-k}|∣ck​∣=∣cn−k​∣﻿ represents the strength of an oscillation with frequency kkk﻿. For 0≤i≤n−10 \leq i \leq n-10≤i≤n−1﻿, we call ∣ck∣2|c_k|^2∣ck​∣2﻿ the (Fourier) power spectrum.

  • The lll﻿ coefficients “around” 000﻿, capture low frequencies (∣cn−l∣,...,∣c0∣,...,∣cl∣|c_{n-l}|,..., |c_0|,...,|c_l|∣cn−l​∣,...,∣c0​∣,...,∣cl​∣﻿)
  • The lll﻿ coefficients “around” n/2n/2n/2﻿, capture high frequencies (∣cn/2−l∣,...,∣cn/2∣,...,∣cn/2+l∣|c_{n/2-l}|,..., |c_{n/2}|,...,|c_{n/2+l}|∣cn/2−l​∣,...,∣cn/2​∣,...,∣cn/2+l​∣﻿)

Low/ High Pass Filtering

  • Therefore a low pass filter is a filter, that preserves the lll﻿ coefficients around 000﻿, but reduces the noise (high frequency coefficients). This can be achieved by zeroing out all high frequency coefficients.
  • A high pass filter is the exact opposite.

A filter operates the following:

  1. Compute DFT of signal → ckc_kck​﻿’s
  1. Modify coefficients ckc_kck​﻿ → c~k\tilde{c}_kc~k​﻿
  1. Compute the DFT−1^{-1}−1﻿ of c~k\tilde{c}_kc~k​﻿ resulting in the filtered signal y~k\tilde{y}_ky~​k​﻿

Signal Changes

Modifications, that do not alter our Fourier coefficients ckc_kck​﻿:

  • Shifting (rotating) the signal y=(y1,y2,...,yn)→(y2,...,yn,y1)y = (y_1,y_2,...,y_n) \rightarrow (y_2,...,y_n,y_1)y=(y1​,y2​,...,yn​)→(y2​,...,yn​,y1​)﻿
  • Reversing the signal (nnn﻿-shifts)

Modifications, that do alter our Fourier coefficients ckc_kck​﻿:

  • Adding a constant to our signal changes the coefficients, since the amplitude of our signal changes.
  • Multiplying by a constant would also result in different coefficients

FFT

FFT saves us time in computing a DFT, which equals a matrix multiplication (FnF_nFn​﻿) that works in time n2n^2n2﻿.

The FFT algorithm is an algorithm to compute the DFT of a signal. It uses the following idea:
We can split the computation of a
2n2n2n﻿ DFT computation into 222﻿ computations of length nnn﻿.

T(n)=2T(n/2)+O(n)=2(2T(n/4)+O(n/2))+O(n)→nlog⁡2(n)T(n) = 2T(n/2)+O(n) = 2(2T(n/4) + O(n/2)) + O(n) \rightarrow n \log_2(n)T(n)=2T(n/2)+O(n)=2(2T(n/4)+O(n/2))+O(n)→nlog2​(n)﻿

VectorXcd fftrec(const VectorXcd &y) {
  const VectorXcd::Index n = y.size();
  if (n == 1) return y;
  if (n % 2 != 0) throw std::runtime_error("size(y) must be even!");
  

  const Eigen::Map<const Eigen::Matrix<std::complex<double>, Eigen::Dynamic,
                                       Eigen::Dynamic, Eigen::RowMajor>>
      Y(y.data(), n / 2, 2);
  const VectorXcd c1 = fftrec(Y.col(0)), c2 = fftrec(Y.col(1));

  const std::complex<double> omega =
      std::exp(-2 * M_PI / n * std::complex<double>(0, 1));

  std::complex<double> s(1.0, 0.0);
  VectorXcd c(n);

  for (long k = 0; k < n; ++k) {
    c(k) = c1(k % (n / 2)) + c2(k % (n / 2)) * s;
    s *= omega;
  }

  return c;
}

Different random circulant matrices have the same eigenvectors!

(Week 10) Polynomial (Inter/Extra)-Polation

Lagrange Polynomial

For a given set {t0,t1,...,tn}⊂R\{t_0,t_1,...,t_n\}\sub\R{t0​,t1​,...,tn​}⊂R﻿ of nodes consider the Lagrange polynomials

Vandermonde Matrix

Multiple evaluations - Barycentric Interpolation Formula

The use of 5.2.3.3 involves

  • computation of weights λi,i=0,...,n\lambda_i,i=0,...,nλi​,i=0,...,n﻿: Cost O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2)﻿ only once!
  • cost O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n)﻿ for every subsequent evaluation of ppp﻿

    → Total asymptotic complexity of O(n2+Nn)\mathcal O(n^2+Nn)O(n2+Nn)﻿

Rewriting the Lagrange Polynomial to be mostly independent of yiy_iyi​﻿ gives us a formula to precompute the polynomial and evaluate it at multiple points. This gives us a runtime of O(n2)\mathcal O (n^2)O(n2)﻿ to construct the polynomial from our nnn﻿ data-points it then has a Runtime of O(Nn)\mathcal O (Nn)O(Nn)﻿ to evaluate NNN﻿ points on the polynomial. But if one wants to add a data point all the λi\lambda_iλi​﻿ need to recomputed which is inefficient.

Single Evaluation - Aitken Neville Scheme

# include <Eigen/Dense>

using Eigen::VectorXd;
/* SAM_LISTING_BEGIN_0 */
// Aitken-Neville algorithm for evaluation of interpolating polynomial
// IN:  t, y: (vectors of) interpolation data points 
//      x: (single) evaluation point
// OUT: value of interpolant in x
double ANipoleval(const Eigen::VectorXd& t, Eigen::VectorXd y, const double x) {
  for (int i = 1; i < y.size(); ++i) {
    // Careful: int loop index required for comparison >= 0 !
    for (int k = i - 1; k >= 0; --k) {
      // Recursion \eqref{eq:ipolrec}
      y[k] = y[k + 1] + (y[k + 1] - y[k])*(x - t[i])/(t[i] - t[k]);
    }
  }
  return y[0];
}

Newton Basis and Divided Differences

The Newton Basis for Pn\mathcal P_nPn​﻿ is given, by the basis functions:

B={1,(t−t0),(t−t0)(t−t1),(t−t0)(t−t1)(t−t2),...,∏i(t−ti)}  ⟹  dim⁡Pn=n+1\mathcal B _{} = \{1, (t-t_0),(t-t_0)(t-t_1),(t-t_0)(t-t_1)(t-t_2), ..., \prod_{i} (t - t_i) \} \implies \dim \mathcal P_n = n+1B​={1,(t−t0​),(t−t0​)(t−t1​),(t−t0​)(t−t1​)(t−t2​),...,∏i​(t−ti​)}⟹dimPn​=n+1﻿

We denote:

N0(t)=1,N1(t)=(t−t0),...,Nn(t)=∏i(t−ti)N_0(t) = 1, N_1(t) = (t-t_0), ..., N_n(t) = \prod_i (t-t_i)N0​(t)=1,N1​(t)=(t−t0​),...,Nn​(t)=∏i​(t−ti​)﻿

To find coefficients for the newton basis, we solve the jjj﻿-th equation:

a0N0(tj)+a1N1(tj)+a2N2(tj)+...+anNn(tj)=yja_0N_0(t_j) + a_1N_1(t_j) + a_2N_2(t_j) + ... + a_nN_n(t_j) = y_ja0​N0​(tj​)+a1​N1​(tj​)+a2​N2​(tj​)+...+an​Nn​(tj​)=yj​﻿

This leads to the system:

Using the Horner Scheme we get an asymptotic effort of O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n)﻿ for a single evaluation of p(t)p(t)p(t)﻿.

Comparison of the 3 algorithms

Evaluation of the Lagrange polynomial interpolant at multiple points xj∈R,j=0,...,Nx_j \in \R,j=0,...,Nxj​∈R,j=0,...,N﻿ provided a given data set {ti,yi}∈R2,i=0,...,n\{t_i,y_i\}\in \R^2,i=0,...,n{ti​,yi​}∈R2,i=0,...,n﻿.

  • The barycentric interpolation formula precomputes some weights {λi},i=0,...,N\{\lambda_i\},i=0,...,N{λi​},i=0,...,N﻿, which costs O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2)﻿ while every subsequent evaluation costs O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n)﻿. In total, the asymptotic complexity is O(n2+nN)\mathcal O(n^2+nN)O(n2+nN)﻿. If one wants to add a new point, a recomputation of all the weights {λi}\{\lambda_i\}{λi​}﻿ is necessary, which makes the barycentric interpolation formula not update friendly.
  • The Aitken-Neville scheme is tailored for a single evaluation with a possibly growing data set. Adding a new data point (ti,yi)(t_i,y_i)(ti​,yi​)﻿ only needs a runtime of O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n)﻿. But for each new evaluation point xxx﻿, the algorithm has to be run again from scratch. This implies an asymptotic complexity of O(Nn2)\mathcal O(Nn^2)O(Nn2)﻿.
  • For the divided difference approach, the coefficients for the New basis are precomputed, which costs O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2)﻿. Adding a new data point (ti,yi)(t_i,y_i)(ti​,yi​)﻿ requires an asymptotic runtime of O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n)﻿. Each subsequent evaluation costs O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n)﻿ if Horner’s scheme is used. In total, it is O(n2+nN)\mathcal O(n^2+nN)O(n2+nN)﻿.

(Week 11) Iterative Methods for Non-Square Systems

Conditions on fixed point iterations

To check consistency of a function Φ\PhiΦ﻿ a solution x∗x^*x∗﻿ of the original Problem F(x)=bF(x)=bF(x)=b﻿ needs to satisfy x∗=Φ(x∗)x^* = \Phi (x^*)x∗=Φ(x∗)﻿ and vice versa.
To check
local convergence check wether ∣∣DΦ(x∗)∣∣<1||\text{D}\Phi(x^*)|| < 1∣∣DΦ(x∗)∣∣<1﻿ holds. If it holds it converges at least linearly.

Implications of theses Conditions

Φ\PhiΦ﻿ is consistent   ⟹  \implies⟹﻿ any convergent sequence converges to a solution x∗x^*x∗﻿

Φ\PhiΦ﻿ is consistent and contractive   ⟹  \implies⟹﻿ Φ\PhiΦ﻿ converges globally and at least linearly

Φ\PhiΦ﻿ is consistent and ∣∣DΦ(x∗)∣∣<1||\text{D}\Phi(x^*)|| < 1∣∣DΦ(x∗)∣∣<1﻿   ⟹  \implies⟹﻿ Φ\PhiΦ﻿ converges locally and at least linearly (if it converges)

Bisection Method

The bisection method to find a zero of a function fff﻿ relies on first having an x0x_0x0​﻿ and x1x_1x1​﻿ with f(x0)<0f(x_0) < 0f(x0​)<0﻿ and f(x1)>0f(x_1)>0f(x1​)>0﻿. We then continue to half the interval from x0x_0x0​﻿ to x1x_1x1​﻿ and replace our bounds, such that the conditions for x0x_0x0​﻿ and x1x_1x1​﻿ still hold. Assuming we find x0x_0x0​﻿ and x1x_1x1​﻿ to start with this method enjoys exponential convergence, since the interval shrinks exponentially.

(Week 12) Newton Method

Newton Method

The newton Method relies on linearly approximating the actual function around an initial guess x′x'x′﻿ and using the root of this approximation as the next guess for the root of the original function.

Newton Iteration: xk+1=xk−F(xk)/DF(xk)x^{k+1} = x^k - F(x^k)/DF(x^k)xk+1=xk−F(xk)/DF(xk)﻿

The runtime mostly depends on the computation of the inverse of the derivative DF(xk)−1DF(x^k)^{-1}DF(xk)−1﻿ of FFF﻿ at xkx^kxk﻿. This step involves finding an LU-Decomposition which has runtime O(n3)\mathcal O(n^3)O(n3)﻿.

template<typename Func, typename Jac, typename Vec>
void newton(Vec& x, Func F, Jac DF, double rtol, double atol)
{
  double ns,nx;         // auxiliary variables for termination control
  do {
		auto lu = DF(x).lu(); // do LU decomposition
	  Vec s;
    s = lu.solve(F(x));
    x = x-s;            // new iterate
    ns = s.norm(); nx = x.norm();
  }
  // \com{termination} based on relative and absolute tolerance
  while((ns > rtol*nx) && (ns > atol));
}

Multi-Point Methods

There are also various variations of the Newton Method using more then just one approximation point. E.g. piece-wise linear approximation with nnn﻿ points or the secant method which is explained below.

Secant Method

(Week 13) Convergence/ Termination of Newtons Method

Simplified Newton Method

Newton Correction: xk+1=xk−DF(x0)−1F(xk)x^{k+1} = x^k - DF(x^0)^{-1}F(x^k)xk+1=xk−DF(x0)−1F(xk)﻿

Advantage: Saves a lot of computation time by having to find the inverse of the derivative in point xxx﻿ only once.

Drawback: Switching to the simplified Newton method usually sacrifices the asymptotic quadratic convergence of the Newton method: merely linear convergence can be expected.

template<typename Func, typename Jac, typename Vec>
void simpnewton(Vec& x, Func F, Jac DF, double rtol, double atol)
{
  auto lu = DF(x).lu(); // do LU decomposition \com{once}!
  Vec s;                // Newton correction
  double ns,nx;         // auxiliary variables for termination control
  do {
    s = lu.solve(F(x));
    x = x-s;            // new iterate
    ns = s.norm(); nx = x.norm();
  }
  // \com{termination} based on relative and absolute tolerance
  while((ns > rtol*nx) && (ns > atol));
}

Convergence of Newtons Method in 1D

Newtons method locally converges quadratically to a zero x∗x^*x∗﻿ of FFF﻿ if F’(x∗)≠0F’(x^*) \neq 0F’(x∗)=0﻿ and FFF﻿ is three times continuously differentiable in the neighborhood of x∗x^*x∗﻿

Newtons method locally converges quadratically to a zero x∗x^*x∗﻿ of FFF﻿ if F’(x∗)≠0F’(x^*) \neq 0F’(x∗)=0﻿ and FFF﻿ is three times continuously differentiable in the neighborhood of x∗x^*x∗﻿

Convergence of Newtons Method

If:

(A) D⊂Rn open and convex, (B) F:D↦Rn continuously differentiable,(C) DF(x) regular ∀x∈D,(D) ∃L≥0:∥DF(x)−1(DF(x+v)−DF(x))∥2≤L∥v∥2∀v∈Rn,v+x∈D,(E) ∃x∗:F(x∗)=0(existence of solution in D )(F) initial guess x(0)∈D satisfies ρ:=∥x∗−x(0)∥2<2L∧Bρ(x∗)⊂D.\text{(A) } D \subset \mathbb{R}^n \text{ open and convex, } \\ \text{(B) } F: D \mapsto \mathbb{R}^n \text{ continuously differentiable,} \\ \text{(C) } \mathrm{D} F(\mathbf{x}) \text{ regular }\forall \mathbf{x} \in D, \\ \text{(D) }\exists L \geq 0: \quad\left\|\mathrm{D} F(\mathbf{x})^{-1}(\mathrm{D} F(\mathbf{x}+\mathbf{v})-\mathrm{D} F(\mathbf{x}))\right\|_2 \leq L\|\mathbf{v}\|_2 \quad \forall \mathbf{v} \in \mathbb{R}^n, \mathbf{v}+\mathbf{x} \in D, \\ \text{(E) }\exists \mathbf{x}^*: \quad F\left(\mathbf{x}^*\right)=0 \quad \text{(existence of solution in D )} \\ \text{(F) initial guess }\mathbf{x}^{(0)} \in D \text{ satisfies } \rho:=\left\|\mathbf{x}^*-\mathbf{x}^{(0)}\right\|_2<\frac{2}{L} \wedge B_\rho\left(\mathbf{x}^*\right) \subset D. (A) D⊂Rn open and convex, (B) F:D↦Rn continuously differentiable,(C) DF(x) regular ∀x∈D,(D) ∃L≥0:​DF(x)−1(DF(x+v)−DF(x))​2​≤L∥v∥2​∀v∈Rn,v+x∈D,(E) ∃x∗:F(x∗)=0(existence of solution in D )(F) initial guess x(0)∈D satisfies ρ:=​x∗−x(0)​2​<L2​∧Bρ​(x∗)⊂D.﻿

Then the Newton Iteration satisfies:

(i) x(k)∈Bρ(x∗):={y∈Rn,∥y−x∗∥<ρ}∀k∈N,(ii) lim⁡k→∞x(k)=x∗,(iii)∥x(k+1)−x∗∥2≤L2∥x(k)−x∗∥22 (local quadratic convergence).\text{(i) } \mathbf{x}^{(k)} \in B_\rho\left(\mathbf{x}^*\right):=\left\{\mathbf{y} \in \mathbb{R}^n,\left\|\mathbf{y}-\mathbf{x}^*\right\|<\rho\right\} \forall k \in \mathbb{N}, \\ \text{(ii) }\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbf{x}^{(k)}=\mathbf{x}^*,\\ \text{(iii)}\left\|\mathbf{x}^{(k+1)}-\mathbf{x}^*\right\|_2 \leq \frac{L}{2}\left\|\mathbf{x}^{(k)}-\mathbf{x}^*\right\|_2^2 \quad \text{ (local quadratic convergence).}(i) x(k)∈Bρ​(x∗):={y∈Rn,∥y−x∗∥<ρ}∀k∈N,(ii) limk→∞​x(k)=x∗,(iii)​x(k+1)−x∗​2​≤2L​​x(k)−x∗​22​ (local quadratic convergence).﻿

Termination Criteria of Newtons Method

The perfect stoping rule would be ∣∣xK−x∗∣∣≤τrel⋅∣∣x∗∣∣||x^K - x^*|| ≤ \tau_{\text{rel}}\cdot ||x^*||∣∣xK−x∗∣∣≤τrel​⋅∣∣x∗∣∣﻿. But this method requires knowing the solution beforehand, which is obviously not practical.
There are various other methods to terminate the Newton Iterartion:

  1. A priori termination

    This method is just stopping the newton iteration after kkk﻿ steps, regardless of closeness to a solution. This can yield highly inaccurate results or waste a lot of runtime.
  1. Residual based termination
    This method stops if
    ∣∣F(xk)∣∣≤τ||F(x^k)||≤ \tau∣∣F(xk)∣∣≤τ﻿, where τ\tauτ﻿ is the prescribed tolerance. This of course assures that F(xk)F(x^k)F(xk)﻿ is close enough to zero, but gives you no information about the size of ∣∣xk−x∗∣∣||x^k-x^*||∣∣xk−x∗∣∣﻿. Which can lead to highly inaccurate results if FFF﻿ is flat around its roots.
  1. Correction based termination
    This method stops if
    ∣∣xk−xk+1∣∣≤τrel||x^k-x^{k+1}|| ≤ \tau_{\text{rel}}∣∣xk−xk+1∣∣≤τrel​﻿. This does also not guarantee, that we are close to x∗x^*x∗﻿, because the function FFF﻿ could be flat around its roots.
  1. Termination Criterion for linearly convergent iterations
    If the iteration is linearly convergent, that is
    ∃0<L<1:∥x(k+1)−x∗∥≤L∥x(k)−x∗∥∀k∈N0\exists 0<L<1: \quad\left\|\mathbf{x}^{(k+1)}-\mathbf{x}^*\right\| \leq L\left\|\mathbf{x}^{(k)}-\mathbf{x}^*\right\| \quad \forall k \in \mathbb{N}_0∃0<L<1:​x(k+1)−x∗​≤L​x(k)−x∗​∀k∈N0​﻿. Then the iteration error can be estimated in the following way: ∣∣xk+1−x∗∣∣≤L1−L⋅∣∣xk+1−xk∣∣||x^{k+1}-x^*|| ≤ \frac{L}{1-L}\cdot ||x^{k+1} - x^k||∣∣xk+1−x∗∣∣≤1−LL​⋅∣∣xk+1−xk∣∣﻿
    Even though it might sometimes be hard to determine the rate of convergence
    LLL﻿, an pessimistic estimate of LLL﻿ will not compromise reliability. But this can of course add computation cost due to needless iterations.

Damped Newton Method

The Newton Iteration does only converge locally, the idea of the damped Newton Method is to sacrifice local quadratic convergence to broaden the range of initial guesses that do converge towards a solution. If one observes the Newton Iteration failing to find a solution this is often due to overshooting. So the idea is to check wether we are overshooting and to decrease the size of the update of the iterate accordingly.
